intro: Gilia iberidifolia, commonly known as the California gilia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Malvaceae family and typically grows in open, sunny habitats such as grasslands and disturbed soils. The plant produces striking clusters of pink to purple flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are lance-shaped and often have a hairy texture, while its stems are upright and branching. Gilia iberidifolia is valued for its ornamental appeal and plays a role in supporting local pollinators.
